title: Why did YouTube delete views from BTS’ ‘Idol’ music video? - Quora

response.answer_text: YouTube users a machine learning algorithm to determine if the views are manipulated. According to Google’s support forum: ‘’After quality views are counted, view count updates more frequently. The process of including all quality views can take some time depending on a video's popularity and viewership. Afterward, the view count updates more frequently, but keep in mind that we're constantly validating views, so view count can always be adjusted.’’ Refering to frozed views, Google furthur states that: ‘’On some videos, the view count might seem frozen or not show all the views that you expect. Video views are algorithmically validated to maintain fair and positive experiences for content creators, advertisers, and users. To verify that views are real and accurate, YouTube may temporarily slow down, freeze, or adjust the view count, as well as discard low-quality playbacks.’’  You see Danel Fentone was among the first 1.1 million viwers but the views froze The same IP address refreshing and replaying the video endlessly will be considered as bot and the views deleted. Any behaviour that shows a pattern will de deleted Views under 30 seconds will be deleted Views from multiple tabs will be deleted Views from multiple browsers from the same IP address will be deleted Views on playlists can be attributed to passive listening but these are important marketing tools on non streaming days Fans have suggested to watch ‘idol’ then 2–3 different BTS music videos , Removal of cookies, then repeat. Due to machine learning algorithm which will recognise pattern behaviours, this strategy should be modified each time one is streaming. For example I watched ‘Idol’ then I watch ‘DNA’ and ‘FAKE LOVE’. Next Time I’ll do ‘Idol’’ then ‘NOT Today’ and ‘NO more dream’ or ‘IDOL’ then ‘ FOR YOU’ , ‘BLOOD SWEAT AND TEARS’ and ‘EPIPHANY’. Since Idol sucessfully achieved genuine 45.9 (List of most-viewed online videos in the first 24 hours - Wikipedia) views on its released day, it means that most ARMYs have been able to stream corrently but some ARMY weren’t streaming corrently To guarantee long term viewship of BTS videos( because this, not the 24 hours record is the ultimate goal) , I suggest fans to share the video links or playlists (Google play, amazon music, genie, melon, orion, apply music, spotify, shazam, youtube ect ) on various social platforms and listen on various devices Danel Fentone's answer to Is BTS still dating? Once again, short answers here! Basically, YouTube is doing it’s job, and deletes and will delete views on a video, regardless of who it is, who’s channel it is, who’s in it, and the whole shebang, If they are bought. People will try to buy views for their favorite artists, for their videos to help them move up on charts and get awards, and it’s very common, especially in the world of, you’ve guessed it, K-Pop. Lots of K-Pop fanbases and fansites, even the companies themselves, set these huge goals for their groups, when they release new music. Then, fans run screaming to the polls, buyer sites, streaming platforms, and YouTube, all to try to stream the views and get the numbers up. So, some people try to help, and they end up buying fake views for the video and such, and when YouTube catches them, the fake views get deleted, and they have every right to. Fake views are harmful, and they really take down the whole purpose, as does streaming. Streaming is as much fake as fake views are. If you’re streaming to bulk up numbers, it’s not really fair, because really, one person should only view the video once or twice. Streaming it to reach goals doesn’t mean you’re always enjoying it. So, if you’re wondering why BTS’ IDOL or other videos loses views, it’s because the views are fake, and YouTube is actually doing it’s job to keep the records as accurate as possible. (Little personal opinion here, don’t stream. It just amounts to a lot of views that aren’t real, and it undermines the whole purpose of finding out how many people have watched it. Like, really.)
